JavaScript is a versatile language that can be used for both front-end and back-end development.
Use 'let' and 'const' instead of 'var' to declare variables for better scope management.
Arrow functions provide a shorter syntax for writing function expressions.
Template literals allow for multi-line strings and string interpolation.
Destructuring assignment makes it easy to extract values from arrays or objects.
The spread operator (...) can be used to expand arrays or objects.
Promises are a way to handle asynchronous operations in JavaScript.
Async/await syntax makes working with promises easier and more readable.
JavaScript has first-class functions, meaning functions can be treated like any other variable.
Use '=== ' for strict equality checks to avoid type coercion issues.
The 'map' method creates a new array populated with the results of calling a provided function on every element in the calling array.
The 'filter' method creates a new array with all elements that pass the test implemented by the provided function.
The 'reduce' method executes a reducer function on each element of the array, resulting in a single output value.
JavaScript's 'this' keyword behaves differently in arrow functions compared to regular functions.
Use 'forEach' to execute a function on each element of an array without returning a new array.
The 'setTimeout' function allows you to execute a function after a specified delay.
The 'setInterval' function allows you to execute a function repeatedly at specified intervals.
JavaScript supports object-oriented programming through prototypes and classes.
Use 'try...catch' for error handling in asynchronous code.
The 'fetch' API provides a modern way to make HTTP requests.
JavaScript has a rich set of built-in methods for manipulating arrays and objects.
Use 'localStorage' and 'sessionStorage' for client-side storage of data.
The 'window' object represents the browser's window and provides methods to interact with it.
JavaScript can manipulate the DOM to create dynamic web pages.
Event delegation allows you to manage events more efficiently by using a single event listener.
Use 'addEventListener' to attach events to DOM elements.
The 'DOMContentLoaded' event fires when the initial HTML document has been completely loaded and parsed.
JavaScript supports modules, allowing you to break your code into reusable pieces.
Use 'import' and 'export' to work with modules in JavaScript.
The 'Math' object provides properties and methods for mathematical constants and functions.
JavaScript has a built-in 'Date' object for handling dates and times.
Use 'JSON.stringify()' to convert a JavaScript object into a JSON string.
Use 'JSON.parse()' to convert a JSON string into a JavaScript object.
The 'console' object provides access to the browser's debugging console.
Use 'console.log()' to print messages to the console for debugging purposes.
JavaScript supports regular expressions for pattern matching in strings.
The 'Array.isArray()' method determines whether the passed value is an Array.
Use 'Object.keys()' to get an array of a given object's property names.
Use 'Object.values()' to get an array of a given object's property values.
The 'slice' method returns a shallow copy of a portion of an array into a new array.
The 'splice' method changes the contents of an array by removing or replacing existing elements.
JavaScript has a 'Promise.all()' method that takes an array of promises and returns a single promise.
The 'async' keyword is used to declare an asynchronous function.
The 'await' keyword is used to wait for a promise to resolve.
JavaScript's 'bind' method creates a new function that, when called, has its 'this' keyword set to the provided value.
The 'call' and 'apply' methods allow you to invoke a function with a specified 'this' value.
Use 'Object.assign()' to copy the values of all enumerable own properties from one or more source objects to a target object.
The 'filter' method can be used to create a new array with elements that meet certain criteria.
JavaScript supports higher-order functions, which can take other functions as arguments.
The 'every' method tests whether all elements in the array pass the test implemented by the provided function.
The 'some' method tests whether at least one element in the array passes the test implemented by the provided function.
Use 'includes()' to check if an array contains a certain value.
The 'indexOf()' method returns the first index at which a given element can be found in the array.
The 'find()' method returns the value of the first element in the array that satisfies the provided testing function.
The 'findIndex()' method returns the index of the first element in the array that satisfies the provided testing function.
JavaScript has a 'Set' object that lets you store unique values of any type.
The 'Map' object holds key-value pairs and remembers the original insertion order of the keys.
Use 'Promise.race()' to return a promise that resolves or rejects as soon as one of the promises in the iterable resolves or rejects.
The 'finally' method of a promise will execute a specified function when the promise is settled, regardless of its outcome.
JavaScript's 'WeakMap' and 'WeakSet' are collections of objects that allow for garbage collection.
The 'Symbol' type is a unique and immutable primitive value that can be used as the key of an object property.
The 'Proxy' object enables you to create a proxy for another object, allowing you to intercept and redefine fundamental operations.
The 'Reflect' object provides methods for interceptable JavaScript operations.
JavaScript supports the 'import.meta' object, which contains metadata about the module.
The 'globalThis' object provides a standard way to access the global 'this' value across different environments.
Use 'requestAnimationFrame()' for smoother animations in the browser.
The 'IntersectionObserver' API allows you to asynchronously observe changes in the intersection of a target element with an ancestor element or with a top-level document's viewport.
JavaScript's 'Service Workers' enable the creation of web applications that can work offline.
The 'Web Storage API' provides storage that is accessible within the client's browser.
Use 'WebSockets' for real-time communication between the client and server.
The 'Fetch API' is a modern interface for making HTTP requests.
JavaScript supports 'WebAssembly' for running code written in other languages at near-native speed.
The 'Canvas API' allows for dynamic, scriptable rendering of 2D shapes and bitmap images.
Use 'SVG' for scalable vector graphics that can be manipulated with JavaScript.
JavaScript's 'Geolocation API' allows you to access the geographical location of a device.
The 'WebRTC' API enables peer-to-peer connections for audio and video communication.
JavaScript supports 'IndexedDB' for storing large amounts of structured data.
The 'File API' allows web applications to read and manipulate files on the user's computer.
Use 'Media Queries' in JavaScript to create responsive designs.
The 'Pointer Events' API provides a way to handle input from a variety of devices.
JavaScript's 'Clipboard API' allows you to interact with the clipboard for copying and pasting.
The 'Notifications API' allows web applications to send notifications to the user.
JavaScript supports 'Web Workers' for running scripts in background threads.
The 'Performance API' provides methods to measure the performance of web applications.
Use 'CSS-in-JS' libraries to style components directly within JavaScript.
JavaScript's 'EventSource' interface allows you to receive automatic updates from a server via HTTP connection.
